citation.article-title: Bacteroides pyogenes sp. nov., Bacteroides suis sp. nov., and Bacteroides helcogenes sp. nov., new species from absesses and feces of pigs

p.s: Description of Bacteroides suis sp. nov.
Bacteroidds suis (su'is. L. n. sus swine; L. gen. n. suis of the pig)]
Obligately anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-motile, non-pigmented, non-sporing rods.
Gram strains of single colonies from agar plates show predominantly short, Gram-negative rods, single or in pairs; longer rods only occasionally (0.4-0.6 μm by 0.5-2.0 μm).
After 2 days of incubation surface colonies are 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter, circular with entire edge, low convex, translucent to opaque, grey to grey-white, shiny and smooth.
Slight greening or indefinite hemolysis often apparent on blood agar plates.
No growth on blood agar plates incubated in a candle-extiction jar or in an aerobic atmosphere.
Cultures in broth moderately turbid with a slight, smooth sediment.
After incubation for 1 day the pH in media containing a fermentable carbohydrate generally decreases to about 5.0 No, or markedly inhibited and delayed, growth in PYFG broth containing 20% bile.
Arabinose, xylose, glucose, manose, fructose, galactose, sucrose, maltose, cellobiose, lactose, melibiose, raffinose, starch, glycogen, inulin, salicin, amygdalin and xylan are fermented.
Trehalose, melezitose, glycerol, adonitol, erythritol, inositol and gum arabic are not fermented.
Nitrate is not reduced; indole or ammonium are not produced.
Acetic and succinic acids and very small amounts of propionic and isobutyric acids are produced in PYFG broth.
All strains are susceptible to penicillin (10 μg/ml).
The G+C content of the DNA is 42.3-45.7 mol%.
The type strain is DSM 20612 ( = P38024), isolated from the feces of a healthy pig.
